Like that's not, there are plenty of Christians who believe it and plenty of Christians who don't, and people have been debating about it at least since the second generation of Christians.
So good news.
You can believe the earth is very, very old and still be a Christian.
And she said, you're kidding me.
I said, no, that's no, no, here's, here's, here's like nine books by people who are godly men and women who have written about it.
And she said, well, then I want to be a Christian.
It's like that was, that was the only barrier she had been told.
Yeah.
This was a barrier between you and following Christ.
And when she learned it was, I was like, oh good.
Okay, good.
Let's do that.
Then it's a great cool.
Can you go on my website and tell everybody how good of a counselor that I am?
In one session.
Which is that by the way, is very weird.
That's not normal.

What counseling is all in fact, I didn't, I prayed with her in that session, which is actually kind of strange for me, but then I required her because some people will become a Christian for counseling homework.
So I don't, I don't usually encourage that.
Yeah.
Who do you know who you love, who you could pray with?
But anyway, it was, it was purely, she had been raised on a belief.
That was all that was keeping her was this, this equals this.
And when she discovered, okay, that doesn't equal that now, now go and figure out what you believe about the age of the earth.
Knock yourself out.
Yeah.
Read the scriptures, read the books, go nuts.
And, but it, but no one should be telling you that that's a prerequisite for, for following Jesus.
Yeah.
And I do think that's a good example of a roadblock for a lot of people because they, and this goes back to what we've already talked about in previous podcasts.
Because they think that Christianity is all about blind faith.
Yes.
And they feel like to become a Christian, I've got to walk away from science and reason.
And, and so they're not willing to do that.
But it's again, you've got this false dichotomy.
Like you don't have to pick between science and faith.
You know what I'm saying?
You can be, you can be both.
I mean, you can believe in both and follow both.
And I think part of what Christianity, I'm sorry, part of what apologetics does is it removes those roadblocks where Christianity is actually plausible for the first time.
Cause like for that lady, it's like, it's not even on my list of options.
If that's what it means, then it can't be.
And you just go, well, like you said, good news.
That's not one of the requirements to become a Christian.
And so the thing that you thought was holding you back actually is not a reason.
You know, that's right.
And again, people will still have excuses or that'll be like their smoke screen.
And then apologetics can also remove that and show that the real issue is that you don't want to.
A lot of the people that are deconstructing their faith, they've left the youth group and they go into college or beyond.
Right.
And even having the conversation of what do you look for in a church is a really important question.
Absolutely.

As far as what are the essentials that I'm going to be fed or the basics that are, that are here, because if you're in the wrong environment, it's going to create either it's going to reinforce this legalism or it's going to make you confused or whatever.
So yeah, what would you say if you're looking for a church?
Oh my gosh.
Um, first off, I do think what you want is someone who is saying we, we defer to the authority of scripture.
Um, we may not always know what scripture says.
We may not, and you want humble attitudes within this.
If you have someone who says, no, we absolutely always know what the Bible says and you need to do what we tell you it says.
That's a, that's a huge red flag.
So you want a humble attitude of, listen, we don't always know what the, what the Bible is teaching us, but we're willing to work hard to try to understand it.
And when we are convinced of what it says, then we defer to the, its authority, whether we like it or not.

And so it's kind of funny, like, uh, in one setting I would say, uh, and this is a question, I actually think that's the line at a fundamental level that may be the line between actual what a Christian is, is someone who defers the authority of scripture, trusts it to teach you.
Again, not with a blind, foolish, unsophisticated way of studying it.
But I think I feel like if someone answers the question, certainly this is what makes an evangelical.
I think that if I asked the question, if you knew for sure, I mean, somehow you knew with a hundred percent certainty that the Bible taught something, would you submit to that?
And so with some populations, I will say, so if you knew absolutely without any shred of doubt that the Bible taught that to engage in homosexual behavior is sin, would you change?
Not, not would you be perfect, but would you go, okay, I agree with that.
I agree with that statement.
I confess that statement.
I will work to obey that statement.
I will, I will trust in God to help me obey that statement.
Or would you say, well, but I, but I still want to do that.
Same thing is true of pre-marital, like so heterosexual sex outside of marriage.
Like, would you?
Okay.
Would you, if you knew that around here, what I say is if you knew with absolute certainty that the Bible taught you that it's wrong to defend yourself.
Like if you came to that conviction that it is wrong to defend yourself.
You can't shoot somebody.
You can't karate chop somebody.
You can't stab somebody with a buoy knife.
Like if someone, if you knew without any doubt that Christian pacifism was what was taught in scripture, would you get rid of all those weapons?
And if the answer is, I just don't think I can.
Okay.
Well, then you're not, you're not really following.
And, and that sounds rigid in some ways, but I think it's a mindset that really is important for us as Christians.
And I want to look for that in a church.
I want to look for a church that says, listen, we don't always know what it says, but when we become convinced, we do know what it says.
That's what we teach.
Well, it's like Martin Luther's famous line of my conscience is held captive to the word of God.
Yeah.
I can't hear, I stand.
I can do, you know what I'm saying?
Like it's God's word is my authority.
And yeah.
And then I think you've said it before related to even those topics, especially about sex and homosexuality.
So you're either ignorant or rebellious.
If you're not following it, like in other words, you didn't know, and now you do know.
Right.
And now that you know, your options are I can, I can be rebellious and do my own thing and still decide, or I can get in line.
Right.
And trust that the words by his Holy spirit is going to empower me, but that's going to be the struggle.
Right.
But I'm, I'm acknowledging, yes, that's what I'm submitting to.
Absolutely.
Yeah.
And that's, that's because you don't want to be, I know this is hard.
It's hard for, it's hard for me as a pastor.
Um, in the end, I don't want a church full of people to follow me.
I don't want a church full of people to follow leadership board or whatever.
Cause we're so frail and limited.
We actually, our leadership board, each time we meet, we sing or pray the old hymn, be thou my vision, which is about, okay, we don't trust us.
We don't trust each other to have right agendas.
And so we don't want to trust at all.
We know in our own understanding to quote the proverb, we want to lean not on our own understanding, but in all our ways, acknowledge him.
I'm going to trust in him with all our heart.
And we don't, um, we know we're even bad at that.
That's how untrustworthy we are.
So you want a church that has a healthy attitude about, we're going to do our best to tell you what scripture teaches to the best of our understanding and encourage you and, and, and, uh,
help you equip you to apply that and live that out.
It's not just what we think.
It's not just what I think.
It's not just what a charismatic leader thinks it's not, and that's our goal.
So that's, that's an example of something cause you need a true North.
I mean, if you're gonna, if you're going to wander through the wilderness, you need something to trust and humans aren't it.
I think it was, I was trying to find the quote, but I think it was GK Chesterton that said, it used to be that we were confident in, in believing in, in trusting in, in truth revealed to us and
skeptical about ourselves.
And he says now it's completely the opposite that we're skeptical about truth and we're totally confident in ourselves that we should trust ourselves.
And that's, that's the danger that you're, that you're in where you're wise in your own eyes, which again, that's biblical.
You know what?
That's, I wonder if we could add, if we should add to our definition of Christianity that we started with is that we are a race in need of saving.
Maybe that's a fundamental, certainly an underlying view of the Judeo-Christian world.
View.
But if there is no sin, there is no Christianity.
So if humans can't sin, if we can't be wretches, if we're somehow capable of fixing this problem on our own, then, then Christianity kind of falls apart.
Because you don't need, you don't need a savior.
Right.
You don't need to be saved from anything.

So maybe we would start there with saying the crown of Christianity, what we're talking about is as we understand scripture to teach Christianity at the basic level, that we need a savior and God, we need a way to, to repair the relationship with God.
And God provided that way through his son.
And that's going to be a fundamental and the nature and character of that God.
There are certain things that are, that are kind of non-negotiable and a lot of things that are negotiable.
And we are, we trust in scripture to reveal to us the truth.
Now I say that, but it's also, and then we have to be good students of studying it and digging into it and wrestling through the disagreements and not avoiding the things we don't like.
And that's the kind of stuff we're looking for.
But again, that's going back to the distinction of, am I happy or is this truth?
In other words, acknowledging that I'm a sinner doesn't make me happy, but is it true?
And that's where so many people today, all they want to talk about is, but is your lifestyle making you happy?
Which that alone, that word can be very dangerous.
But Coles and I were talking about parenthood earlier because a lot of people, if you've got this wrong view of God, that he's supposed to always be made happy.
And he's always making me happy.
Yeah. He would never want me to suffer.
He would never want me to struggle.
Every parent knows if you're going to be a good parent, that's not your goal.
Do I have a happy child?
Because we make them go to bed.
We make them, we tell them not to eat this, but to eat that.
You don't always get your way.
You can't watch, you know, Disney movies until three in the morning.
Every, every parent knows I'm going to do things that make you uncomfortable or not always happy.
But it's, and again, it's because I love you.
Right.
I'm going to self-destruct if I don't step in.
And so again, if your view of God is that he never lets bad things happen to you, then well, of course that God let you down.
Right.
But that's not the real God.
You had a straw man faith.
So, you know, in this, in this podcast, I don't know that we have given some good, complete, clear, concise definition of Christianity.
In fact, I feel like we certainly haven't.
And maybe that's just because that's, that's not something we're capable of doing that, that well.
But what, when we talk about our faith, when we talk about Christianity on this podcast, we're going to be talking about the fundamentals as much as possible.
I'm sure we will unpack details, but we're not talking about a certain denomination.
We're not talking out of a certain polity or church politics.
We're not going to be talking about that.
That's not the focus of, of this podcast.
We don't, what we want people to have are the, the building blocks to reconstruct the fundamentals of their faith as they're engaging with it.
When someone faces that deconstruction, when they realize, wait a minute, this is a chain that's been holding my foot down and it's not real.
It doesn't have to hold me down.
It's not accurate.
That's the going through the underroot of the underwear drawer that we talked about a few podcasts ago.
Well, then what am I going to put back in?
And that's what we want to challenge people with.
Okay.
How are you going to, what do you believe about truth?
What do you believe about faith?
What are these things and how do you then engage with and test?
Okay.
This I keep this I toss.
Um, this I keep this I toss.
I listened to a little bit of one of our earlier podcasts the other day.
Um, and, and I was, I was talking about the, um, uh, that the underwear drawer mindset of, okay, I need to, I need to test this as the Bible says test all of it and keep that, which is right.
What the apostle Paul says, we need to test it and figure out and you'll do it your whole life.
And maybe that's troubling for people.
Maybe they'd rather just be told, listen, this is the right answer and it's all good and that's it, but I feel like it's more complicated.
It's more challenging.

It's a relationship with an actual person and that's always harder than just, well, and I think too, that's why legalism is always appealing is you, it allows you to look religious, but you don't have to have a heart change.
Yeah.
Like I just tell me what to do.
It's just all the, the, the rigid stuff, the rules that I should follow, but there's no real relationship or heart, heart change there.
Yup.
Is that just cause it's, it's easier to kind of tick off, take that off the checklist.
I think, well, okay, I'm good with God.
Well, I don't know.
Do you think it's easier and that's why people like it more?
Yeah.
Well, it's, it's convenient in that I can, there's a difference between fitting my life into Christ and fitting Christ into my life.
Like, but it that way, like there's one way I'm adding him onto, uh, like the schedule is mine, but Jesus gets an appointment versus the schedule is his, like he's fully sovereign or.
You know, he's a character in my story versus he's the director producer star.
You know what I mean?
Yeah.
I have a role.

So I think it is easier just if I get to add that on versus it totally consumes everything about me and that's where Jesus gives a pretty high call of if you're not willing to give up everything, then you're not worthy to be my disciple or to follow me.
Like that's what I'm asking you to do.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org.
Reconstructed faith is a resource of South spring Baptist church.
Remember, don't give up trust God search for answers.

<description><p>The post <a href="https://southspring.org/reconstructed-faith-defining-christianity/">5. Reconstructed Faith &#8211; Defining Christianity</a> appeared first on <a href="https://southspring.org">South Spring Baptist Church</a>.</p>
</description>
<content:encoded><div class="et_pb_section et_pb_section_49 et_section_regular" >
				
				
				
				
				
				
				<div class="et_pb_row et_pb_row_49">
				<div class="et_pb_column et_pb_column_4_4 et_pb_column_49  et_pb_css_mix_blend_mode_passthrough et-last-child">
				
				
				
				
				<div class="et_pb_module et_pb_text et_pb_text_45  et_pb_text_align_left et_pb_bg_layout_light">
				
				
				
				
				<div class="et_pb_text_inner"><p><strong>Defining Christianity // Show Notes </strong></p>
<p>1:55 &#8211; Legg’s Project about Salvation </p>
<p>5:55 &#8211; Velvet Elvis comments </p>
<p>What has to be true?<br />What do I have to believe?<br />What could I believe wrongly and then have the wrong god?</p>
<p>7:25 &#8211; Sherrod comment about talking to Mormon about salvation  </p>
<p>8:13 &#8211; Voddie Baucham story </p>
<p>8:25 &#8211; Legg’s Convo with Islamic apologist  </p>
<p>10:40 Sherrod’s definition of Christianity <br />⁃ Essentials/most foundational things of Christianity<br />⁃ God is one, but exists in 3 parts, father, son and holy spirit<br />⁃ Equal in essence<br />⁃ Son came to earth, was fully god and fully man &#8211; Hypostatic union<br />⁃ As we understand scripture to teach Christianity, we need a savior &#8211; a way to repair the broken relationship with God, and God provided that way through his son Jesus.<br />⁃ Salvation &#8211; Jesus lived the life we should have lived, died the death we should have died, rose again and conquered death. He offers this to us freely.</p>
<p>12:55 &#8211; What separates Christianity from everything else. Everything else spells salvation as: D-O. Works based salvation.<br />Christianity spells salvation: D-O-N-E. Christ has done the work for us to be saved.</p>
<p>13:17 &#8211; Two diagnostic questions: <br />⁃ Do you know for certain that if you were to die today you would go to heaven? 1 John 5:13 “I write these things to you who believe in the son, that you may know that you have eternal life.&#8221;</p>
<p>⁃ If you were to die, and God was to say “Why should I let you into my heaven?,” what would you say?</p>
<p>16:14 &#8211; Short definition when we, at Reconstructed Faith, talk about Christianity<br />⁃ We are talking about the Christ-centric faith, the provision and revelation of the Holy Bible (Old and New Testaments).</p>
<p>17:17 &#8211; Trusting God for something he hasn’t promised.<br />⁃ Sheep Analogy<br />⁃ Very often the faith that people deconstruct should be deconstructed<br />⁃ Tim Keller quote &#8211; if someone says they don’t believe in God, he’ll say describe for me the god you rejected, because I may not believe in him either.</p>
<p>18:00 &#8211; Sheep discussion with Sherrod</p>
<p>19:00 &#8211; Sherrod Christianity “Box” analogy</p>
<p>20:40 &#8211; Legg, Elephant discussion</p>
<p>23:20 &#8211; Roadblock example &#8211; Age of the Earth </p>
<p>25:25 &#8211; False Dichotomy some people have<br />⁃ Having to choose between science and faith</p>
<p>26:55 &#8211; what to look for in a church conversation<br />⁃ Deferring to the authority of scripture &#8211; humble attitude</p>
<p>31:45 &#8211; if you’re going to wander through the wilderness, you need a true north, something to trust. Humans aren’t it.</p>
<p>32:00 &#8211; G. K. Chesterton quote &#8211; It used to be that we were confident in trusting in truth revealed to us, and skeptical about ourselves. Now it is the exact opposite. Now we are skeptical about truth and confident to trust ourselves.</p>
<p>34:45 &#8211; Legg unpacking of Christianity definition  </p>
<p>36:38 &#8211; The appeal of legalism is that it allows you to look religious without heart change</p>
<p>37:00 &#8211; Difference between legalism and relationship</p>
<p><strong>Key Quotes from the Episode</strong></p>
<p><em>It’s a wild conversation just how short the list is about what you have to know and believe in order to be a Christian.</em></p>
<p><em>A lot of people are deconstructing a faith that 1) never was their own faith, essentially jumping because their parents in front of them jumped (see sheep analogy, 18:00) or 2) they have built into it all these expectations of God who, for example, will never let me go through pain, or who always makes me happy. Unfortunately if you believe that about God you’re going to be disappointed.</em></p>
<p><em>When you read the scripture for yourself, you are either set free in a positive way to believe the God who is (not the God I was raised on), or you’re set free to not worship anything but myself because I don’t trust anything but myself.</em></p>
<p><em>What Christians needs to do is deconstruct the childish faith they have, the “Santa-Clause” faith they have.</em></p>
<p><em>In rebelling against the false stuff in your beliefs, you don’t have to throw everything away. Just the false stuff.</em></p>
<p>&nbsp;</p></div>
